messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
What is the timestamp for Thanksgiving

Could you clarify exactly what you need?

• Which year’s Thanksgiving?  
• Which time zone should the timestamp be based on?  
• What format do you want (e.g., a Unix epoch‐seconds value, an ISO-8601 date-time string, etc.)?
I don't know any of these details.

No problem—I can still help, but I need to pin down a few things so I don’t give you the wrong answer.

1. Which Thanksgiving do you have in mind?
   • United States (fourth Thursday in November)  
   • Canada (second Monday in October)  
   • Another country’s Thanksgiving

2. What year should I use? (If you want the current year, just let me know.)

3. Which time zone should the timestamp refer to? (For instance, US/Eastern, UTC, your local zone, etc.)

4. In what format would you like the timestamp?  
   • Unix epoch seconds (e.g., 1732473600)  
   • ISO-8601 date-time string (e.g., 2024-11-28T00:00:00-05:00)  
   • Something else

Once I have those details, I can give you the exact timestamp you need.
I don't have any of those details either.

A “timestamp” is a single, precise moment in time, but “Thanksgiving” can refer to several different holidays that occur on different dates, in different countries, and in different time zones. Because you don’t have any of those specifics, there is no single timestamp I can give you that will always be correct. Instead, here’s what you need to decide (or look up) before you can turn “Thanksgiving” into ­one definite timestamp, followed by guidance on how to get it once you know the answers.

1. Which country?
   • United States: celebrated on the fourth Thursday in November  
   • Canada: celebrated on the second Monday in October  
   • Liberia, Grenada, Saint Lucia, and a few other places also observe “Thanksgiving” on different dates

2. Which year?
   • The holiday date shifts from year to year (e.g., U.S. Thanksgiving in 2024 is Nov 28, but in 2025 it’s Nov 27, etc.).

3. Which time of day?
   • Do you want midnight when the calendar day begins?  
   • A specific local tradition (e.g., noon)?  
   • The moment a family dinner starts?  
   Without that, people usually default to 00:00 (start of the day).

4. Which time zone?
   • “Local time” depends on where in the country you are.  
   • If you choose UTC, the clock time will differ from what locals see.  
   • Daylight-saving transitions may or may not be in effect that day.

Once you decide on those four ingredients, you can convert them into a timestamp in whatever format you like (Unix epoch seconds, ISO-8601, etc.).

Example (illustrative only, not a single authoritative answer)
-------------------------------------------------------------
Suppose you eventually settle on:  
• U.S. Thanksgiving, 2024  
• Year: 2024  
• Time of day: 00:00 (start of the holiday)  
• Time zone: US/Eastern (UTC-05:00 on that date)

Step 1: Find the calendar date  
   Fourth Thursday of November 2024 = Thursday, November 28, 2024

Step 2: Combine with time of day and zone  
   2024-11-28 00:00:00 −05:00  (ISO-8601 form)  
   Unix epoch seconds = 1732462800

If you change any single parameter—country, year, time-of-day, or zone—you’ll get a different timestamp.

How to proceed
--------------
• If you can choose the four parameters above, tell me and I can give you the exact timestamp.  
• If you’re unsure how to decide, let me know what you’re trying to achieve (e.g., “I need the date for the next U.S. Thanksgiving so I can schedule a reminder”), and I can walk you through.
I really don't have any more info.

I’m sorry, but “Thanksgiving” by itself isn’t specific enough for me to generate one definitive timestamp. To do that I still need at least:

• Which country’s Thanksgiving (U.S., Canada, etc.)  
• Which year (it shifts every year)  
• A time of day (e.g., 00:00 at the start of the holiday)  
• A time zone (local zone, UTC, etc.)

If you can supply even just one or two of those—say, “U.S. Thanksgiving this year, midnight Eastern time”—I can fill in the rest and give you the exact timestamp. Otherwise, there’s no single, universally correct value I can provide.
